head.title: Easing the Path To Good Citizenship

hedline.hl1: Easing the Path To Good Citizenship

abstract.p: Many workers complain it is difficult for them to get to the polls on Election Day, although 31 states have voter-leave laws that give workers at least two or three hours off while polls are open (S)

block.p: Time-starved workers complain that voting on Election Day is much easier said than done.
For them, a trip to the polls means squeezing in yet another errand before work, taking an extended lunch hour or sneaking out early.
It may not have to be that stressful.

For them, a trip to the polls means squeezing in yet another errand before work, taking an extended lunch hour or sneaking out early.
It may not have to be that stressful.

According to Firstdoor.com of Kennesaw, Ga., a human resources consulting firm, 31 states have voter-leave laws that require that workers be off for at least two to three hours while the polls are open. New York has a voter-leave law, while Connecticut and New Jersey do not.
Kimberlee S. Ullner, Firstdoor's director of human resources and of legal compliance, said many workers were unaware of such laws.

Although voter-leave laws vary by state, she said, there are similarities. Twenty-four states require employers to pay for the time that employees need to vote; 17 require employees to request time off in advance. Some have both requirements.

For employers, she said, noncompliance can result in fines -- $25 in Arkansas and up to $20,000 in Arizona. In 12 other states, employers can receive jail sentences of 30 days to a year. The laws ''are aimed at encouraging employers to be good corporate citizens and for employers to vote,'' she said.
